Question Text: Another term for POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is _______________.
Choices:
a. Public Available Telephone Exchange
b. Phone Switched Transport Network
c. Public Available Telephone Network
d. Public Switched Telephone Network
e. Public Switched Telephone Exchange
LLM Explanation: POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is another term for the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN). The PSTN is the traditional circuit-switched telephone network that has been in use for many decades. It is a global system that provides voice communication services over analog telephone lines.

Question Text: A baud rate is a measurement of the number of ______________________.
Choices:
a. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
b. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every second
c. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every second
d. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
LLM Explanation: Baud rate is a measure of the number of signal or symbol changes that occur per second. In digital systems, a symbol change typically corresponds to one bit. Therefore, baud rate measures the number of bits that can be transmitted per second over a communication channel like a telephone line.

Question Text: What system did Duke grads build that is still in use today?
Choices:
a. PSTN
b. POTS
c. DSL
d. USENET
LLM Explanation: USENET, a worldwide distributed discussion system, was developed by graduate students Tom Truscott and Jim Ellis at Duke University in 1979. It allowed users to read and post messages to newsgroups. While not as widely used today, USENET is still accessible and some newsgroups remain active. PSTN (Public Switched Telephone Network) and POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service) refer to the traditional telephone system, while DSL (Digital Subscriber Line) is a family of technologies that provide internet access over telephone lines. These were not specifically created by Duke graduates.

Question Text: Which device is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection?
Choices:
a. USENET
b. Modem
c. Ethernet cables
d. ATM
LLM Explanation: A modem (modulator-demodulator) is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection. It converts digital signals from a computer into analog signals that can be transmitted over telephone lines and then converts the analog signals back into digital signals at the receiving end.

Question Text: Modems take data that computers can understand and turn them into _____ that can be transmitted over POTS.
Choices:
a. Modulating electrical charges
b. PSTN
c. Audible wavelengths
d. Baud rates
LLM Explanation: Modems convert digital data from computers into audible analog signals (wavelengths) that can be transmitted over Plain Old Telephone Service (POTS) lines. The modem modulates the digital data into these audible tones for transmission and demodulates the tones back into digital data on the receiving end.

Choices:
a. Transportation System 1
b. Transmission 1
c. Transmission System 1
d. Transportation 1
LLM Explanation: T1 is short for Transmission 1. It refers to the original transmission system used in telecommunications, capable of transmitting digital signals at 1.544 Mbps. T1 lines are commonly used to provide dedicated point-to-point digital connections for voice and data communications.
URLs: ["Newton, H. (2006). Newton's Telecom Dictionary (22nd ed.). CMP Books.", 'Horak, R. (2007). Telecommunications and Data Communications Handbook (2nd ed.). Wiley-Interscience.']

Question Text: How fast is a T1 line?
Choices:
a. 44.763 Mb/sec
b. 128 Mb/sec
c. 1 Mb/sec
d. 1.544 Mb/sec
LLM Explanation: A T1 line is a dedicated digital carrier line that provides a transmission rate of 1.544 megabits per second (Mb/sec). This is equivalent to 24 voice channels, each operating at 64 kilobits per second (kb/sec). T1 lines are commonly used for business-level Internet access and point-to-point connectivity.

Question Text: Select all statements that are true of cable internet connections.
Choices:
a. They're shared bandwidth connections
b. They're dial-up connections
c. They're broadband connections
d. They're wireless connections
LLM Explanation: Cable internet connections are shared bandwidth and broadband connections. They are not dial-up or wireless connections. Shared bandwidth means the connection is shared among multiple users in a neighborhood, which can lead to slower speeds during peak usage times. Broadband refers to high-speed internet access that is faster than traditional dial-up connections.

Question Text: What are the subprotocols for PPP (Point to Point Protocol)? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. LCP
b. Compression
c. FCS
d. NCP
LLM Explanation: The two main subprotocols of PPP are:a) Link Control Protocol (LCP): Establishes, configures, and tests the data-link connection. It is responsible for negotiating connection parameters.  d) Network Control Protocol (NCP): Responsible for configuring different network-layer protocols over the data link. Each network-layer protocol (like IP, IPX, AppleTalk, etc.) has its own NCP.b) Compression is an optional feature that can be negotiated by LCP, but not a subprotocol itself.c) Frame Check Sequence (FCS) is a field in the PPP frame for error detection, but not a subprotocol.

Question Text: What do you call the demarcation point for fiber technologies?
Choices:
a. ONT
b. FTTN
c. DSLAM
d. FTTX
LLM Explanation: The demarcation point for fiber technologies is called an Optical Network Terminal (ONT). The ONT is the device that terminates the fiber optic line from the service provider and converts it into a usable interface for the customer, such as Ethernet. It serves as the point of division between the service provider's network and the customer's premises wiring.

Choices:
a. Wireless Area Network
b. Wide Area Network
c. Wired Area Network
d. Wireless Local Area Network
LLM Explanation: WAN stands for Wide Area Network. A WAN is a computer network that extends over a large geographic area, connecting different LANs (Local Area Networks) and MANs (Metropolitan Area Networks). WANs enable communication between computers and devices in remote locations, often using leased telecommunication lines or satellite links.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. J. (2011). Computer Networks (5th Edition). Pearson.']

Question Text: In a WAN, what is the area between a demarcation point and the ISP's core network known as?
Choices:
a. a local loop
b. A local link
c. a Local Area Network
d. An access point
LLM Explanation: In a Wide Area Network (WAN), the area between a demarcation point (the point where the responsibility for the network switches from the customer to the service provider) and the Internet Service Provider's (ISP) core network is known as the local loop. The local loop, also referred to as the 'last mile', is the physical link or circuit that connects the customer's premises to the ISP's nearest point of presence or central office.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a ______________.
Choices:
a. data link VPN
b. port forwarding VPN
c. one-to-many VPN
d. site-to-site VPN
LLM Explanation: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a site-to-site VPN. It is a type of VPN that connects two specific sites or networks, allowing secure communication between them over the public Internet. The VPN gateway at each site establishes an encrypted tunnel, making it appear as if the two networks are directly connected.
URLs: ['Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Networks v7.0 - Chapter 8: Network Layer', 'CompTIA Security+ (SY0-601) Cert Guide, Chapter 5: Virtual Private Networks']

Question Text: Who handles sending data from one site to another?
Choices:
a. ISP
b. VPN
c. T-carrier line
d. CTO
LLM Explanation: The Internet Service Provider (ISP) is responsible for sending data from one site to another over the Internet. ISPs own and maintain the infrastructure that connects individual users and organizations to the global Internet, allowing data to be transmitted between different sites and networks.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/network-layer/what-is-an-isp/']

Question Text: How many address fields does an 802.11 header contain?
LLM Explanation: The 802.11 header contains 3 address fields. These are:1. Destination MAC Address: Specifies the MAC address of the final recipient.  2. Source MAC Address: Specifies the MAC address of the original sender.3. BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier): Specifies the MAC address of the access point in infrastructure mode, or the address of the creator of an ad-hoc network.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Choices:
a. a point-to-point wireless connection
b. Individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network
c. a collision domain
d. an example of an ad-hoc network
LLM Explanation: Wireless channels are individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network. The frequency band is divided into these smaller channels to allow multiple devices to communicate simultaneously without interfering with each other. Each channel operates on a specific frequency within the band.
URLs: ['CWNA Certified Wireless Network Administrator Study Guide by David D. Coleman and David A. Westcott', '802.11 Wireless Networks: The Definitive Guide by Matthew S. Gast']

Question Text: Which of the following frequencies do wireless networks typically operate on? Select all that apply.
LLM Explanation: Wireless networks commonly operate on the 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequency bands. The 2.4GHz band is more widely used and compatible with many devices, while 5GHz offers higher speeds but shorter range. 1.544GHz is not a standard frequency for Wi-Fi, and 88MHz falls in the FM radio broadcast range.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11 Wireless LAN Standards: https://standards.ieee.org/standard/802_11-2016.html', 'Wi-Fi Alliance: https://www.wi-fi.org/discover-wi-fi/wi-fi-certified-6', 'Cisco Networking Academy: CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Chapter 26: Fundamentals of Wireless Networks']

Question Text: WPA3 was built with the intention of replacing which protocol?
Choices:
a. WLAN
b. IEEE 802.11
c. WEP
d. WPA2
LLM Explanation: WPA3 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 3) was developed as a replacement for WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2). WPA3 aims to enhance Wi-Fi security by introducing new features such as improved password-based authentication, increased cryptographic strength, and better protection against brute-force attacks. While WPA3 is built upon the IEEE 802.11 standard, it is not intended to replace the standard itself, but rather to provide an updated security protocol for Wi-Fi networks.
URLs: ['Wi-Fi Alliance. (2018). Wi-Fi Alliance® introduces Wi-Fi CERTIFIED WPA3™ security. https://www.wi-fi.org/news-events/newsroom/wi-fi-alliance-introduces-wi-fi-certified-wpa3-security', 'Cisco. (2018). Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3). https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/what-is-wpa3.html']

Question Text: An 802.11 frame contains a number of fields. Which field describes the version of 802.11 that is being used?
Choices:
a. Duration
b. Sequence control
c. Address
d. Frame control
LLM Explanation: The frame control field in an 802.11 frame contains information about the 802.11 protocol version being used. This field is present in all 802.11 frames and helps devices identify and interpret the frame correctly based on the 802.11 standard version.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types']
